key_points: Governor General of New Zealand, Patsy Reddy, revealed Prince Harry and Meghan considered moving to New Zealand in 2018.
The couple discussed this possibility during their visit to the Abel Tasman national park.
Reddy viewed their conversation as informal, focusing on the couple's future and family-raising plans.
The discussion of relocating occurred less than six months after their wedding and before moving to the US.
Prince Harry and Meghan eventually stepped back from royal duties and relocated to the US.
In an interview with Oprah Winfrey, the couple mentioned considering a move to a Commonwealth country like New Zealand.
Reddy will leave her ceremonial role in October after a five-year term.
She sends hand-typed letters to the Queen, sharing personal perspectives on New Zealand.
Despite some New Zealanders' republican sentiments, Reddy supports maintaining the monarchy.
Childrenâ€™s advocate Cindy Kiro, the first Indigenous woman, will succeed Reddy.
